revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jeff Richards | image = Jeffrichards2.jpg | image_size = 100px </gallery> | imagesize = 100px | caption = Jeff Richards 2009 | birthname = Jeffrey Hanson Richards | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|10|21}} | birth_place = [[Walnut Creek, California]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Actor/Comedian | years_active = 2000–present | spouse = | domesticpartner = | website = }}
'''Jeffrey Hanson Richards''' (born October 21, 1974)<ref>[http://tastyjeff.com/tasty/?page_id=5 Jeff Richard's bio on his official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003002840/http://tastyjeff.com/tasty/?page_id=5 |date=2011-10-03 }}</ref><ref name=IMDB>{{IMDb name|id=0724145|name=Jeff Richards}}</ref> is an American actor, stand-up comedian and [[impressionist]]. Richards has the distinction of being the first person ever to be a cast member on both ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' ''(SNL)'' and its rival sketch show, ''[[MADtv]]''.<ref name=COLLEGE>{{cite web |url=http://www.collegehumor.com/article:1771620|title=Jeff Richards (aka Drunk Girl)|last=Klocksien |first=Jake |date=March 3, 2009 |work= |publisher=College Humor |accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=HOOPLA>{{cite web|url=http://hooplanow.com/tag/jeff-richards/ |title=Best bets April 14 to 20 |last=Weber |first=Carly |date=April 14, 2011 |work= |publisher=Hoopla |accessdate=September 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326104019/http://hooplanow.com/tag/jeff-richards/ |archivedate=March 26, 2012 |df= }}</ref> He is perhaps best known for his frequent ''SNL'' character "Drunk Girl".<ref name=COLLEGE/><ref name=HOOPLA/><ref name=KCTV5>{{cite web |url=http://events.kctv5.com/Jeff_Richards/220238803.html|title=Events: Jeff Richards|last=|first=|date=April 29, 2011|work= |publisher=[[KCTV]]|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
As a standup comedian, Richards has opened for the likes of [[Chris Kattan]], [[Andrew Dice Clay]], [[Rob Schneider]], [[David Spade]], [[Louie Anderson]], and [[Andy Dick]]. He has appeared as a guest on [[Marc Maron]]'s ''WTF'' podcast as well as on [[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]] and [[NBC]]'s ''Late Night''.
==Early years== Richards was born in [[Walnut Creek, California|Walnut Creek]], [[California]] and attended [[Las Lomas High School]].<ref name=SFGATE>{{cite web |url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2004-07-19/entertainment/17436466_1_show-hug-east-bay|title=After 'SNL,' Jeff Richards is moving on to movies. First came public access.|last=Ganahl |first=Jane |date=July 19, 2004 |work= |publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref> At age 17, he created and hosted his own [[public access]] sketch comedy show called ''Hanson Live''.<ref name=COLLEGE/><ref name=SFGATE/> He later worked for [[KVHS]], a student-run radio station which broadcasts from [[Clayton Valley High School]].<ref>[http://www.kvhs.com/Alumni.htm KVHS Alumni] Retrieved September 3, 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://my.hsj.org/Schools/Newspaper/tabid/100/view/frontpage/schoolid/121/articleid/63814/newspaperid/97/8216The_Edge8217_station_room_to_be_remodeled.aspx |title=‘The Edge’ station room to be remodeled |last=Nelson |first=Onna |date=June 15, 2005 |work= |publisher=''The Talon'' (Clayton Valley High School newspaper) |accessdate=September 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320120128/http://my.hsj.org/Schools/Newspaper/tabid/100/view/frontpage/schoolid/121/articleid/63814/newspaperid/97/8216The_Edge8217_station_room_to_be_remodeled.aspx |archivedate=March 20, 2012 |df= }}</ref> He then attended the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] (UNC) and, in his senior year, he joined the [[improvisational comedy]] team [[CHiPs Improv|CHiPs]].<ref name=COLLEGE/> Fellow CHiPs member Zach Ward brought Richards to the comedy club Charlie Goodnights in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], where he performed at an [[open mic]] show; Richards would eventually go on to host at the club.<ref name=COLLEGE/>
After graduating from UNC, Richards moved to [[Los Angeles]] to further develop his comedy career.<ref name=SFGATE/>
==Career==
After moving to LA, Richards worked the door at [[The Comedy Store]] and eventually started to perform stand-up.
In 2000, Richards became a featured player in the cast of ''[[MADtv]]'', appearing in 3 episodes of the show's [[MADtv (season 6)|6th season]]. The following year Richards joined the cast of ''Saturday Night Live'' during its [[Saturday Night Live (season 27)|27th season]], giving him the distinction of being the first person to be a cast-member of both [[sketch comedy]] shows ([[Taran Killam]] would later become the only other performer to do so). Richards was promoted to repertory status for ''SNL'''s [[Saturday Night Live (season 29)|29th season]] although he left the show after the 10th episode, which aired on January 17, 2004. In interviews, Richards has stated that he left the show on his own terms.<ref name=SFGATE/>
Perhaps Richards' most popular character on ''SNL'' was "Drunk Girl", who appeared on the ''[[Weekend Update]]'' segment nine times. He based the character on an audience member he encountered while performing stand-up at [[The Comedy Store]] in [[La Jolla]], [[California]].<ref name=COLLEGE/><ref name=DECENTLY>{{cite web |url=http://feeds.feedburner.com/DecentlyFunny|title=Decently Funny with Nuzzy and Guy Episode #63: Jeff Richards urine my apartment|last=|first=|date=April 26, 2011 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
In 2004 Richards appeared in the [[Comedy Central]] year-end retrospective special ''Last Laugh '04'' as [[Fox News]] commentator [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]]. In 2006 he again portrayed O'Reilly in episode of ''[[Mind of Mencia]]'' titled "Carlos Smoov".<ref name=IMDB/>
In 2007 he appeared on episode 22 of ''[[Comics Unleashed with Byron Allen]]'' along with comics Jeff Jena, [[Natasha Leggero]], and [[Mike Epps]].<ref>[http://www.es.tv/comics-unleashed/category/comedians/jeff-richards/ Jeff Richards on ''Comics Unleashed with Byron Allen''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011192432/http://www.es.tv/comics-unleashed/category/comedians/jeff-richards/ |date=2011-10-11 }}. Retrieved September 3, 2011</ref>
Richards has also done voice work which includes characters in the 2004 video game [[EverQuest II]], a character in the 2006 [[MTV]] animated series ''[[Where My Dogs At?]]'' and in 2010 he played the voice of [[Brad Pitt]] in an episode titled ""The Wedding" of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] sitcom ''[['Til Death]]''.<ref name=IMDB/>
Richards produced a comedic album titled ''A$$WAX'' which was released on iTunes on March 3, 2009;<ref name=COLLEGE/><ref>[https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/a$$wax/id302411290 ''A$$WAX''] on [[iTunes]]</ref> a portion of the proceeds from the album's sales was used to fight world hunger.<ref name=COLLEGE/> Richard also performed in a series of comedy benefit shows called "Asswax 4 Hunger" in 2009; the shows were hosted by friend [[Kato Kaelin]]. Richards and Kaelin also hosted a podcast called [https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/in-pod-we-trust/id421004708 In Pod We Trust] in 2011.
In 2009 Richards played the character of Jerome Murphy in episode 3 of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[science fiction]] series ''[[FlashForward]]''.<ref name=IMDB/> That same year Richards appeared in the pilot episode of a sitcom created by comedian [[Bill Burr]] called ''The Burr Effect'' which appeared on [[Comedy Central]];<ref name=IMDB/> the series did not get picked up by the network.
Over his career Jeff has also appeared on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' and ''[[The Late Late Show (CBS TV series)|The Late Late Show with Craig Kilborn]]''.<ref name=KCTV5/>
==Celebrity impersonations featured on ''Saturday Night Live''== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Louie Anderson]] (whom he also portrayed on ''MADtv'') * [[Burt Bacharach]] * [[Lance Bass]] * [[Gary Busey]] * [[Howard Dean]] * [[Fred Durst]] * [[Al Franken]] * [[Josh Gracin]] * [[Dustin Hoffman]] * [[Curly Howard]] * [[Steve Irwin]] * [[David Letterman]] (whom he also portrayed on ''MADtv'') * [[Rush Limbaugh]] * [[Michael Moore]] * [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] (whom he also portrayed in an episode of ''Mind of Mencia'') * [[Phil McGraw|Dr. Phil]] * [[Charlie Rose]] * [[Pete Rose]] * [[Karl Rove]] * [[Garry Shandling]] (whom he also portrayed on ''MADtv'') * Siegfried from [[Siegfried and Roy]] * [[Kevin Spacey]] * [[Gene Wilder]] }}
==Filmography== *''The Hand Job'' (2005) *''Projectorhead'' (short film) (2006) * ''Sheep Man'' (short film) (2006) * ''Bad Mofos'' (short film) (2011)
== References == {{reflist}}
